I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In 2005, the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan requested technical assistance 
(TA) from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for preparing the Second Education Sector 
Reform  Project  (the  Project).  The  TA  is  included  in  the  2006–2008  country  strategy  and 
program update.1 ADB is currently financing the Education Sector Reform Project (ESRP),2 the 
implementation progress of which is fully satisfactory. The Fact-Finding Mission was undertaken 
in March 2006, and reached agreement with the Government on the impact, outcome, scope, 
cost estimates, financing plan, implementation arrangements, and terms of reference for the 
proposed TA.3
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Since its independence in 1991, the Republic of Tajikistan has had increasing difficulties 
maintaining the universal primary education and high literacy  achieved during the Soviet period. 
Declining  budget  resources  and  rising  poverty  have  caused  deterioration  in  the  quality  of 
education and a decline in access to primary and secondary education by school-age children. 
The consequences of the civil war that ended in 1997 further worsened access to and quality of 
education, particularly for the poor. The gross enrollment rate in basic education was 84.5% in 
2004, compared with 97% in 1991.  
 
3.  The  Government’s  goal  is  to  establish  a  relevant  education  system  that  provides 
universal  access  to  quality  education  for  the  country’s  children  and  young  people,  and  is 
appropriate to the country’s needs. Tajikistan has taken significant steps to reform the education 
sector and to ensure equity and equality with respect to quality education. However, major 
challenges remain.  
 
4.  Insufficient funding is an obstacle to the delivery of quality education. State expenditure 
on education was 3.2% of GDP or 17.1% of the public budget in 2004, compared with 2% of 
GDP or 16% of the public budget in 2000. More efficient use of resources and improvements in 
education financing are needed to improve the quality of education and ensure equitable access. 
On  the  demand  side,  poor  families,  especially  those  with  many  school-age  children,  are 
particularly burdened by the direct costs of education (e.g., books, clothing, stationery, and 
informal payments). The country’s annual population growth rate (about 2%) is the highest 
among the Central Asian republics. More than 74% of the population resides in rural and remote 
mountainous areas. The education system is under growing pressure to improve the school 
infrastructure and ensure that students reaching school age over the next 10 years will have 
access  to  education.  Educational  quality  is  deteriorating  because  of  funding  constraints, 
particularly in rural areas. Gender disparity is emerging: in 2004 just 38% of girls were enrolled 
in  grades  9–11.  School  attendance  and  completion  rates  in  lower  and  upper  secondary 
education are lower for girls than for boys.4
 
5.  The curriculum is currently overloaded with subjects and content requirements that do 
not reflect modern learning methodologies. The national curriculum development policy and

framework needs to take into account standards, student competencies, textbook content, and 
the national student assessment system. Several education sector funding agencies have been 
revising the curriculum and developing textbooks, including the ADB-supported ESRP, which is 
supporting  curriculum  revision  for  two  subjects  in  two  grades.  Despite  external  support, 
textbooks,  learning  materials,  and  learning  aids  are  still  lacking,  particularly  in  secondary 
education, and in the languages of ethnic groups.   
 
6.  The learning assessment systems lack modern approaches for improving (i) the quality 
of education of school children transiting from primary to secondary education, (ii) assessment 
of what students learn during the school year, and (iii) assessment of school graduates entering 
higher education institutions. The Government established two national testing centers in 2006 
to assess the knowledge of high school graduates entering universities. However, the learning 
assessment systems need to be strengthened and modernized.  
 
7.  Teacher remuneration and incentives are low, making it difficult to attract and retain 
teachers for science and language subjects, particularly in rural areas. There is a lack of 
science, language, and information communication technology teachers in secondary education, 
particularly  in  remote  mountainous  areas.  Stronger  support  for  strengthening  teachers’ 
professional  development,  including  in-service  teacher  training,  is  required  to  support  and 
successfully implement reforms in the curriculum and the learning assessment system. 
 
8.  The  Government’s  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  paper,  which  was  endorsed  by  the 
Parliament in June 2002, notes that the efficient and equitable provision of basic social services 
to vulnerable groups is an effective approach to poverty reduction. In 2005, about 63% of the 
population lived below the poverty line. The Government is updating the Poverty Reduction 
Strategy paper for 2006–2010, and is developing the National Development Strategy for 2006–
2015. The National Strategy for Educational Development (NSED) for 2006–2015 sets out key 
priorities in the education sector, serves as an overall strategy for education reforms, and 
includes plans for achieving the education-related Millennium Development Goals, and the 
Education For All objectives. The NSED requires detailed plans in order to implement the 
overall strategy for education reforms. 
 
9.  The TA design builds on the initial achievements of and experience gained under ADB-
supported projects, in particular the Social Sector Rehabilitation Project5 and the ongoing ESRP, 
supported by the ongoing the School Improvement Project6 and attached TA.7 These projects 
have provided assistance in accordance with the country’s sector priorities in the areas of 
education, poverty reduction and economic growth. The TA outcomes will build on results 
achieved by these projects, and include improving access to education in rural mountainous 
areas, developing an education management information system at the MOE, based on data 
collected through school mapping, and strengthening MOE capacity in education planning and 
management.  
 
10.  A major lesson learned is the importance of aid coordination in addressing sector-wide 
policy  and  strategy  priorities.  The  TA  will  be  closely  coordinated  with  the  grant  from  the

external agencies), in order to ensure consistent support for sector reform and development. 
Given  the  importance  of  aid  coordination,  the  TA  will  prepare  a  project  to  support  the 
Government’s plan to initiate a sector-wide approach initiative by 2008. Other lessons learned 
include the importance of stakeholder participation and community involvement in project design. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The TA will prepare a project that will contribute to an improved education system 
responsive to the needs of a modern economy and supportive of poor, disadvantaged children, 
particularly girls and children with special needs. The TA design and monitoring framework is in 
Appendix 1. 
 
12.  The project proposal will address key issues facing the education sector, and will include 
technical reports outlining recommendations regarding (i) a school development plan, (ii) a plan 
for developing and providing textbooks and learning materials, and (iii) a plan for modernizing 
learning assessment and teacher development. The project proposal will be in a format suitable 
for funding by ADB and consistent with the NSED.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA will assist the Government review and update sector policies, analyze sector 
needs, and outline recommendations for action plans. It will assess achievements, progress, 
and remaining priorities, taking into consideration progress under the ESRP and projects funded 
by other funding agencies. Specific TA activities will include (i) identifying key medium- and 
long-term  reform  measures  and  assessing  policy  alternatives;  (ii)  reviewing  sector  policy 
documents, strategies and action plans to address priorities and investment needs; and (iii) 
providing interim and final reports containing detailed proposals for the project design, detailed 
cost estimates, institutional arrangements, and fiscal implications. The TA will (i) analyze current 
education sector expenditures and make recommendations on improving system efficiency and 
resource allocation and utilization; and (ii) review the medium-term expenditure framework for 
the education sector, focusing on fiscal sustainability, and prioritize functions by capital and 
recurrent  expenditures.  These  activities  will  lay  the  groundwork  for  initiating  a  sector-wide 
approach initiative. The TA will include a study tour for MOE and Ministry of Finance education 
planning and financing specialists to an ADB member country, to facilitate the exchange of 
experience regarding alternative approaches for delivering and financing education services. 
The TA will ensure direct participation of key education stakeholders through close consultation. 
The TA will focus on the three principal areas outlined below. 
 
14.  Sustainability of School Facilities. The TA will examine school rehabilitation needs 
nationwide, based on the results of the MOE’s recent school mapping surveys and aid agencies’ 
studies and reports; it will focus on the investment needs of schools in remote mountainous 
areas with the lowest enrollment and attendance rates. Based on these surveys and school 
mapping  results,  the  TA  team  will  determine  school  capacity  utilization,  and  needs  for 
rehabilitation and upgrading of the school network. The TA will recommend necessary changes 
in building standards and requirements, and prepare a school development plan, with costs,

4   
which prioritizes the remaining investment needs. The plan will serve as the basis for school 
development reform measures and investment activities under the project. The TA will also 
examine issues related to school accessibility for disadvantaged children and children with 
special needs. 
 
15.  Curriculum, Textbooks, and Learning Materials. The TA will review (i) the national 
curriculum, including curriculum content, plans, standards, requirements, and competencies; (ii) 
the national policy on curriculum development; and (iii) initiatives undertaken by the ongoing 
ESRP and other funding agencies. The TA will identify current and medium-term needs for 
textbooks, learning materials, teachers’ guidebooks, and learning aids, particularly for subjects 
in which the most severe shortages are being experienced. Based on these assessments, the 
TA will outline recommendations for a plan for providing textbooks and learning materials. The 
plan will be used as the basis for developing textbooks and learning materials under the project. 
Particular attention will be given to the needs of ethnic groups and children with special needs. 
The TA will also prepare recommendations for a teacher training action plan, based on the 
curriculum, textbooks, learning materials, and learning assessment. 
 
16.  Learning Assessment and Teacher Development. The TA will review and analyze the 
capacity of existing learning assessment systems for using objective and performance-based 
methods for assessment of children’s attainment at primary and secondary schools. The TA will 
identify key reform measures and outline recommendations for a modernization plan for learning 
assessment systems, drawing on relevant international experience. The plan will incorporate 
current Government initiatives in learning assessment, including the establishment of a national 
testing center. The action plan will be used as the basis for project activities in developing 
learning assessment systems. 
 
17.  The  TA  will  review  reform  priorities  in  the  area  of  teacher  development,  including 
training, professional development programs, incentives, and remuneration. In addition, the TA 
will  assess  education  financing,  decentralization  of  education  management,  private  sector 
participation in the delivery of educational services, the fostering of community participation, and 
gender equality in education. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $471,000 equivalent. The Government has 
requested that ADB finance $400,000. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA 
funding program. ADB will finance domestic and international consulting services, production of 
reports, equipment, organization of workshops, field surveys, studies, a working study tour, and 
administrative  and  support  services.  The  Government’s  contribution,  estimated  at  $71,000 
equivalent, will be in kind. It will include the provision of counterpart staff, office accommodation, 
workshop and conference facilities, general office support, and exemptions from taxes and 
duties for TA inputs. The Government has been informed that approval of the TA does not 
commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are 
in Appendix 2. 
   
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The MOE will be the Executing Agency for the TA, and will provide counterpart staff 
support and suitably furnished office space for the TA team. The deputy minister of education 
will be the national TA director, and will oversee TA implementation. Current thematic working 
groups at the MOE will form a technical committee to work closely with the project preparatory

5
TA team on the TA objectives. The thematic groups will be supervised by the national director. 
The national steering committee for the ongoing ESRP will provide policy guidance for the TA, 
to ensure continuity between the ongoing and ensuing projects. The national steering committee 
will  be  chaired  by  the  vice  prime  minister  responsible  for  social  sectors  and  include 
representatives from the MOE.  
 
20.  The TA will be implemented over 6 months, from September 2006 to February 2007. An 
inception report will be submitted within the first 2 weeks of TA implementation. An initial draft 
project proposal will be submitted by the end of the third month. A draft final report will be 
submitted at the end of the fifth month, including a draft loan project design in a format suitable 
for funding by ADB. A final report will be submitted 2 weeks after the planning workshop, which 
is to be held upon submission of the draft project design. 
 
21.  Key  education  sector  stakeholders  will  participate  directly,  through  consultation  and 
focus  group  discussions.  Parents,  students,  teachers  and  education  staff,  rural  community 
leaders, parliamentary groups, the business community, and nongovernment organizations will 
provide input on major issues, policy recommendations, and education outcomes. Surveys and 
direct interviews of education sector stakeholders will be conducted to collect baseline data. 
Workshops will be held for stakeholders in urban and rural areas to discuss the outcomes of 
surveys  and  interviews,  and  to  agree  on  policy  recommendations  and  sector  investment 
priorities. 
 
22.  The  TA  provides  for  10  person-months  of  international  consulting  services  and  34 
person-months of domestic consulting services. The team of consultants will comprise the 
following: (i) education economist/planner (team leader) (international consultant, 4 person-
months); (ii) education finance specialist/economist (domestic consultant, 7 person-months); (iii) 
curriculum, textbooks, and learning materials specialists (international consultant, 3 person-
months; domestic consultant, 12 person-months [2 persons at 6 months each]); (iv) learning 
assessment and teacher development specialists (international consultant, 3 person-months; 
domestic  consultant,  6  person-months);  (v)  civil  engineer  (domestic  consultant,  6  person-
months); (vi) poverty/gender specialist (domestic consultant, 3 person-months). The TA will also 
provide for research assistants and support staff. ADB will engage consultants through a firm 
using  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  and  the  simplified  technical  proposal  procedure  in 
accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory 
to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. Office equipment will be procured by the 
consultants in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines and will be turned over to the 
MOE upon TA completion. Detailed terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 4. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Tajikistan for preparing the Second Education Sector Reform Project, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
 OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Overview 
1.  Implementation  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  require  10  person-months  of 
international consulting services and 34 person-months of domestic consulting services. The 
team of consultants will comprise the following (detailed terms of reference are provided below): 
(i) education economist/planner (team leader) (international consultant, 4 person-months); (ii) 
education finance specialist/economist (domestic consultant, 7 person-months); (iii) curriculum, 
textbooks  and  learning  materials  specialists  (international  consultant,  3  person-months; 
domestic consultant, 12 person-months [2 persons at 6 months each]); (iv) learning assessment 
and  teacher  development  specialists  (international  consultant,  3  person-months;  domestic 
consultant, 6 person-months); (v) civil engineer (domestic consultant, 6 person-months); (vi) 
poverty/gender specialist (domestic consultant, 3 person-months). 
 
B.  Terms of Reference 
1.  Education Economist/Planner (Team Leader) (international, 4 person-months) 
2.  As team leader, the education economist/planner will supervise and coordinate the work 
of the team members, act as spokesperson for all major issues, and be the principal focal point 
for the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Ministry of Education (MOE). Working closely 
with the national TA director, the team leader will be responsible for meeting all TA reporting 
requirements, producing quality and timely TA outputs, and preparing the proposed project 
design in compliance with all ADB requirements. The team leader will ensure that the TA is 
implemented based on a stakeholder participation strategy, with the active participation of key 
stakeholders from the central and local governments, educational institutions, and external 
funding agencies. The education economist/planner will provide technical inputs as required in 
the various TA activities, and will  
(i)  provide  technical  expertise  to  the  MOE  in  reviewing  and  realigning  national 
sector policy documents with the MOE’s sector needs;  
(ii)  assess achievements, progress, and remaining priorities of the ongoing ADB-
supported Education Sector Reform Project (ESRP) and projects funded by other 
aid agencies;  
(iii)  assess aid coordination;  
(iv)  prepare a detailed feasibility study to support the second ESRP (the Project) 
design;  
(v)  together with the education finance specialist, analyze current expenditures and 
develop recommendations to improve the efficiency of resource allocation and 
utilization;  
(vi)  review  a  medium-term  expenditure  framework  for  the  education  sector, 
prioritizing functions by capital and recurrent expenditures, for inclusion in a draft 
project framework;  
(vii)  together with the TA team specialists, prepare reports outlining recommendations 
on plans for (a) school development, (b) developing and providing textbooks and 
learning  materials,  and  (c)  modernizing  learning  assessment  and  teacher 
development; and  
(viii)  prepare  an  economic  and  financial  analysis  of  TA  activities,  develop  costs 
associated with the proposed project, and estimate the cost implications beyond 
the proposed project’s lifetime.

Appendix 3  9 
3.  The team leader will also (i) determine the scope for further private sector involvement in 
the education sector; (ii) identify preparatory groundwork for piloting a sector-wide approach 
initiative under the project, and (iii) plan and organize a working study tour to an ADB member 
country to facilitate exchange of knowledge and to learn about alternative methods for delivering 
and financing educational services.  
 
4.  The education economist/planner will design the following activities of the proposed 
project (i) education financing, (ii) decentralization of education management, and (iii) fostering 
community participation in education. 
2.  Education Finance Specialist/Economist (domestic, 7 person-months) 
5.  The  specialist,  under  the  supervision  of  the  team  leader  will  (i)  analyze  current 
expenditures and develop recommendations to improve the efficiency of resource allocation and 
utilization; (ii) review a medium-term expenditure framework for the education sector, prioritizing 
functions  by  capital  and  recurrent  expenditures;  and  (iii)  prepare  economic  and  financial 
analyses (a) of TA activities, (b) for developing the costs of the proposed project, and (c) for 
estimating cost implications beyond the project’s lifetime; (iv) determine the scope for further 
private sector involvement in the education sector and identify principal barriers to education 
service delivery by private operators; (v) assist in identifying preparatory groundwork for piloting 
a sector-wide approach initiative; (vi) identify key medium- and long-term reform measures and 
assess the cost of alternatives; (vii) outline recommendations for sector policy documents, 
strategies, and action plans to address priorities and investment needs; and (viii) prepare a 
detailed feasibility study to support the proposed project design. 
 
3.  Curriculum, Textbooks and Learning Materials Specialists (international, 3 
person-months; domestic, 12 person-months [2 persons x 6 months each]) 
6.  The  specialists will (i) work primarily with the MOE and the Pedagogical Academy, in 
close cooperation with external funding agencies and the National Curriculum Board, to review 
and  realign  the  current  national  curriculum  (curriculum  content,  plans,  standards,  and 
requirements) with the unified policy on curriculum development, including initiatives undertaken 
in  the  ongoing  ESRP;  (ii)  provide  technical  reports,  with  outlined  recommendations,  for  a 
national curriculum development strategy; (iii) identify and analyze current and medium-term 
needs for textbooks, learning materials, teacher guidebooks, and learning aids, particularly for 
subjects in which the most severe shortages are being experienced; (iv) provide technical 
reports, with outlined recommendations, for a strategy for developing and providing textbooks 
and learning materials, which will be used as a basis for project activities; (v) analyze  the needs 
of the different ethnic groups for learning materials, focusing on both the quantitative needs for 
textbooks  and  the  qualitative  aspects  to  be  reflected  to  ensure  cultural  and  gender 
appropriateness; (vi) analyze the needs of children with special learning needs; (vii) support the 
team leader in defining monitoring and performance indicators for the ensuing project; and (viii) 
outline  recommendations  for  developing  a  time-bound  plan  on  in-service  teacher  training 
modules, based on the realigned curriculum, textbooks and learning materials. 
 
4.  Learning Assessment and Teacher Development Specialists (international, 3 
person-months; domestic, 6 person-months) 
7.  The specialists will (i) review and analyze the capacity of existing learning assessment 
systems  for  using  objective  and  performance-based  methods  for  assessment  of  children’s 
attainment at primary and secondary schools; (ii) identify key reform measures for modernizing

10  Appendix 3 
learning  assessment  systems,  drawing  on  relevant  international  experience;  (iii)  outline 
recommendations for a time-bound action plan and associated costs, which should incorporate 
(a) Government initiatives in learning assessment systems, including the establishment of the 
national testing center, and (b) the recommendations on the action plan, which will be used as 
the basis for the project activities relating to the development of learning assessment systems; 
(iv)  outline  recommendations  for  developing  a  strategy  and  plan  for  teacher  development 
initiatives, including in-service training, professional development, remuneration and incentives; 
(v) support the team leader in defining monitoring and performance indicators on learning 
assessment and teacher development for the ensuing project, as well as identifying the scope 
for private sector involvement and community participation. 
 
5.  Civil Engineer (domestic, 6 person-months)  
8.  The specialist will (i) work primarily with the MOE capital construction department to 
examine the rehabilitation needs of schools nationwide, based on recent MOE surveys of 
schools and aid agencies’ studies and reports, focusing on the investment needs of schools in 
remote mountainous areas with lowest enrollment and attendance rates; (ii) based on this 
assessment,  prepare  a  schools  development  plan  with  associated  costs,  detailing  the 
investment needs of priority schools. The plan will serve as the basis for planning school 
development reform measures and investment activities under the project. The specialist will 
also outline recommendations on updating building standards and requirements, and examine 
issues relating to school accessibility for disadvantaged children and children with special needs. 
The specialist will (i) conduct an environmental assessment of the impact of potential civil works 
under the project and will develop an environmental assessment review framework based on 
environmental screening criteria; (ii) clarify the status of land to be used for civil works under the 
project  to  ensure  that  no  displacements  that  could  trigger  ADB’s  policy  on  involuntary 
resettlement will occur; and (iii) support the team leader in defining monitoring and performance 
indicators for the proposed project. 
 
6.  Poverty/Gender Specialist (domestic, 3 person-months) 
9.  The specialist will (i) conduct the TA’s poverty and social analysis to ensure linkages to 
the National Strategy for Education Development and updated Poverty Reduction Strategy, and 
maximum coverage by the project of poor and vulnerable children; (ii) undertake stakeholder 
analysis, based on a stakeholder participation strategy, to (a) ensure maximum participation by 
poor and vulnerable groups in implementation of the TA and project, and (b) explore the 
relevance and adequacy of current curriculum for poor, disadvantaged and female students, 
ethnic groups, and students with special needs; (iii) identify and analyze potential gender-
related issues, including reasons for the low enrollment, attendance, and completion of girls in 
lower and upper secondary education, which are to be considered in the project design and to 
be included in a plan on addressing gender issues in education; (iv) advise on approaches to 
improve learning achievement among disadvantaged children, girls, ethnic groups, and children 
with special needs; (v) collect and analyze statistical data, disaggregated by gender, area, and 
poverty status; and (vi) together with the team’s curriculum, textbook, and teacher development 
specialists, (a) analyze the needs of the different ethnic groups for learning materials, focusing 
on both the quantitative need for textbooks and qualitative aspects to be addressed to ensure 
cultural and gender appropriateness; and (b) analyze the needs of children with special needs; 
and (vii) support the team leader in defining monitoring and performance indicators for the 
proposed project.

Appendix 4  11 
INITIAL POVERTY AND SOCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 
       
Is the sector identified as a national    Yes  Is the sector identified as a national   Yes 
priority in country poverty analysis?      priority in country poverty partnership   
      No  agreement?      No 
 
Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Tajikistan: 
The Government of Tajikistan is strongly committed to providing education to its citizens. Access to education and the 
quality of education are the main priorities outlined in the nation’s Poverty Reduction Strategy and the national 
Strategy for Education Development (2006–2015). Education is the key to better human development, a better 
workforce and an educated society, and leads to better income opportunities, but also to higher value of education 
benefits by parents for their children, and thus an escape from the poverty trap. The predominant focus of the TA on 
the poor will contribute to preparation of the proposed project, which will aim to reduce poverty, contribute to 
sustainable economic growth, and in particular will address the gap emerging between urban and rural schools in the 
quality of and access to education.  
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                      Targeting Classification: Targeted Intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
The TA will conduct a poverty and social analysis, reflecting the priority placed on poverty eradication  by the National 
Strategy for Education Development and the updated Poverty Reduction Strategy with the Project’ impact and 
maximum coverage of poor and vulnerable children under Project.  
 
The stakeholder analysis will ensure the relevance and adequacy of the current curriculum for poor, disadvantaged 
groups, and children with special learning needs. The analysis will identify potential gender issues to be considered in 
the project design. The TA will broadly address learning achievement among disadvantaged children, girls, and ethnic 
groups; and children with special learning needs. Statistical data will be disaggregated by gender, area, and a poverty 
index. 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
 
The stakeholder analysis will ensure the direct participation of parents, students, teachers and education staff, rural 
community leaders, parliamentary groups, business community, and nongovernment organizations in education 
issues and policy recommendations.  
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
 
The stakeholder participation strategy will be implemented through surveys and direct interviews to be conducted by 
the TA team. A series of workshops with the education stakeholders’ groups at central and rural levels will be 
organized to discuss surveys outcomes and to draw conclusions for policy recommendations, sector development, 
and priority investments. 
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women:   
 
There is no gender discrepancy in primary education, with universal access to education for girls and boys. However, 
the latest statistics indicate an emerging gender discrepancy in lower and upper secondary education, and in 
particular a high dropout rate for girls in grades 9–11. The TA will assess issues of gender equality in education by 
focusing on mechanisms to increase secondary education enrollment, attendance, and completion by girls.  
 
Has an output been prepared?      Yes     No 
 
The TA will prepare a plan to address gender priorities in education under the project.
